lens.lens_summary: A first-time guest who has never used a shared-living platform reveals that the entire guest journey must be self-evident at every step, because users scan rather than read, satisfice rather than optimize, and muddle through rather than learn — meaning the platform must eliminate every unnecessary question mark from discovery through active lease.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Vince found the Nolita listing and reached out to Split Lease without fully understanding the service model. His first words after pleasantries are about his schedule uncertainty ('I'm still waiting on them to make things official,' 0:39). He arrives at discovery not through a clear understanding of the platform but through a specific listing that matched a geographic need. Krug's First Law says the home page must be self-evident — 'Oh, it's a _____' — but Vince's confusion at 1:19-1:33 ('How does this work? Is it like a hotel? Multiple people throughout the week?') proves he did NOT achieve that instant recognition from whatever he saw on the platform. He is scanning, not reading, and satisficing — he found something near his job and clicked. The discovery phase must make the service concept obvious within seconds, not require a phone call to explain it.

user_state.emotional_state: Cautiously curious but uncertain. Vince is polite and engaged but clearly has not formed a mental model of how the service works. His tone is exploratory, not committed. He apologizes for scheduling difficulties (0:04: 'Sorry about this'), suggesting slight anxiety about inconveniencing someone.
user_state.knowledge_level: Vince knows he needs a place near the Financial District for 2 nights a week. He does NOT know what Split Lease is, how shared living works, what a 'ghost roommate' means, or how pricing is structured. At 1:19 he explicitly says 'I've never done something like this.'
user_state.commitment_level: Browsing to evaluating. He reached out about a specific listing, which shows intent beyond idle browsing, but his schedule is not yet confirmed and his employer has not finalized his in-office days. He is exploring options, not ready to commit.
user_state.data_available: Geographic preference (Financial District / Nolita), approximate schedule (2 nights/week), job context (engineering, new hybrid role), timeline (roughly 4 weeks out), permanence (ongoing, not short-term).

reasons: Vince does not understand the service model from the listing or website alone — he needed a phone call to learn the basics
His schedule is not yet confirmed by his employer, giving him a reason to delay
Krug's satisficing principle means if the discovery page doesn't instantly communicate 'this is flexible housing for hybrid workers,' Vince will bounce to a competitor or traditional sublet
dropout_risk.evidence: Vince at 1:19-1:33: 'How does this work like is, uh, like there's a full kitchen in there, you know, are you splitting it with like a hotel, like multiple, multiple people, multiple people throughout the week where you clean everything out and you go home or what?' — This string of questions reveals that the platform's self-presentation failed to make the concept self-evident. Krug Ch.1: 'When I look at a Web page it should be self-evident. Obvious. Self-explanatory. I should be able to get it — what it is and how to use it — without expending any effort thinking about it.'

key_quotes.quote: How does this work like is, uh, like there's a full kitchen in there, you know, are you splitting it with like a hotel, like multiple, multiple people, multiple people throughout the week where you clean everything out and you go home or what?
key_quotes.relevance: This is the most important quote for the discovery phase. It proves the platform did not make the service concept self-evident. Vince's mental models — hotel, Airbnb, traditional roommate — are all wrong, and he needs a human to correct them. The discovery phase must do what this phone call had to do: explain the concept in under 10 seconds.

key_quotes.quote: It means that as far as is humanly possible, when I look at a Web page it should be self-evident. Obvious. Self-explanatory. I should be able to 'get it' — what it is and how to use it — without expending any effort thinking about it.
key_quotes.relevance: Krug's First Law is violated by whatever Vince saw before the call. The service concept is novel enough that it requires explicit, prominent explanation — not buried in fine print or assumed to be understood.

key_quotes.quote: What they actually do most of the time (if we're lucky) is glance at each new page, scan some of the text, and click on the first link that catches their interest or vaguely resembles the thing they're looking for.
key_quotes.relevance: Vince scanned, saw a listing in Nolita near his job, and reached out. He did not read enough to understand the service model. Discovery design must account for this scanning behavior by making the value proposition the most visually prominent element.

search.what_this_lens_reveals: Vince's search behavior was location-first. He found a specific listing on Mulberry Street in Nolita (1:02-1:07) and reached out about it directly. He did not describe browsing multiple listings or comparing options. When asked if he would consider other locations if the Nolita studio was unavailable, he immediately said 'Yeah' (3:52-4:02), showing he is flexible but started with a single geographic anchor. Krug's satisficing principle explains this perfectly: Vince found the first reasonable option near his workplace and acted on it. He did not optimize. The search phase must support this 'first reasonable match' behavior by surfacing the most relevant listing quickly, rather than requiring extensive filtering. Krug's convention principle also applies: search/filter patterns must follow established conventions (location, price, dates) so Vince does not have to think about how to search.

user_state.emotional_state: Focused but not invested in any specific listing. Vince mentions the Nolita listing casually and pivots easily when alternatives are suggested. He is pragmatic, not emotionally attached to the space yet.
user_state.knowledge_level: Vince knows his target neighborhood (near Financial District) and his schedule needs (2 nights/week). He does NOT know how to evaluate listings on this platform, what 'ghost roommate' means in practice, or what price range is normal for this type of arrangement.
user_state.commitment_level: Satisficing. He found one listing that seemed close enough and inquired. He has not compared options or done deep research. Classic Krug Fact of Life #2: 'We choose the first reasonable option.'
user_state.data_available: Target location (Financial District / Nolita), schedule (Sunday-Monday nights), amenity requirement (kitchen), willingness to consider alternatives.

reasons: If search results do not surface relevant listings quickly, Vince will satisfice elsewhere (Craigslist, Airbnb, traditional sublet)
Unconventional search parameters (nights per week, ghost roommate compatibility) may confuse a first-time user
Krug warns that every question mark adds to cognitive workload — if the search interface requires Vince to learn new concepts before searching, he will leave

Yeah, I wouldn't be, um, that's just, yeah.' — Vince's easy pivot shows he has low attachment to any single listing. If the platform does not surface a good match quickly, he has no reason to persist. Krug Ch.2 (p.24-25): 'We choose the first reasonable option... Optimizing is hard, and it takes a long time. Satisficing is more efficient.'

key_quotes.quote: The one you reached out about is in Nolita, it looks like it's between, um, right on Mulberry.
key_quotes.relevance: Confirms Vince found a specific listing by location. His search was geographic, not feature-based. The search interface must prioritize location-based discovery.

key_quotes.quote: If this one isn't available. Are you open to other locations if they're close to the financial district? Yeah.
key_quotes.relevance: Vince satisficed on the first listing but is open to alternatives. The platform should proactively suggest similar listings rather than requiring the guest to restart a search.

key_quotes.quote: Most of the time we don't choose the best option — we choose the first reasonable option, a strategy known as satisficing.
key_quotes.relevance: Explains Vince's search behavior perfectly. The platform should optimize for surfacing the first reasonable match, not for displaying the maximum number of options.

listing_evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: Vince evaluated the Nolita listing enough to reach out but not enough to understand the service model. His evaluation was surface-level: location (Mulberry Street), proximity to work (Financial District), and whether it had a kitchen (4:13-4:25). He did NOT evaluate ghost roommate logistics, pricing structure, lease terms, or cleaning protocols — all of which emerged as questions during the call. This maps directly to Krug's scanning behavior: Vince scanned the listing for the few things that matched his immediate needs (location, kitchen) and ignored or did not see everything else. The listing page must make critical differentiating information — especially the ghost roommate concept, the nightly pricing model, and the flexibility mechanism — impossible to miss during a scan. Krug's visual hierarchy principle demands that these novel concepts be more prominent than standard listing details, not less.

user_state.emotional_state: Intrigued but confused. Vince liked the listing enough to reach out but arrived at the call with fundamental misunderstandings about the service. His questions at 1:19-1:33 reveal he expected something more like a hotel or traditional sublet.
user_state.knowledge_level: Vince evaluated: location (yes), kitchen (yes). He did NOT evaluate: pricing model, roommate arrangement, storage, cleaning, lease flexibility, or platform legitimacy. His knowledge gaps are enormous relative to what he needs to make a decision.
user_state.commitment_level: Low-to-medium. He reached out, which shows more than casual interest, but his questions are all foundational ('How does this work?'), not detailed ('Can I store a second monitor?'). He is still deciding whether the concept works for him, not whether this specific listing is right.
user_state.data_available: Listing location and basic amenities (kitchen). Everything else is unknown to the guest at this point.

key_quotes.relevance: Vince's primary amenity filter is a kitchen. He evaluated this from the listing. But he did NOT evaluate the ghost roommate model, pricing, or flexibility — revealing what the listing made scannable vs. what it buried.

Someone who would live in the space when you're not there, that you would never share this space. Um, and you're able to like kind of store your stuff in between stays.
key_quotes.relevance: This explanation from the agent should have been self-evident from the listing page itself. The ghost roommate concept, personal storage, and exclusive-when-there guarantee are the service's key differentiators and must dominate the listing's visual hierarchy.

key_quotes.quote: The more important something is, the more prominent it is. Things that are related logically are also related visually. Things are nested visually to show what's part of what.
key_quotes.relevance: The listing page's visual hierarchy must place the novel service concept (ghost roommate, exclusive use, storage) at the TOP of the hierarchy, above standard details like photos and amenities, because it is the most important thing for a first-time user to understand.

key_quotes.quote: Make it obvious what's clickable... it's important to make it obvious what's clickable and what's not.
key_quotes.relevance: On the listing page, the path from 'I understand this' to 'I want to proceed' must be unmistakable. If Vince finishes scanning the listing and cannot instantly see how to take the next step, the cognitive load compounds.

proposal_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Vince never reached the proposal creation phase during this call. The agent collected his preferences verbally: 2 nights/week (later corrected to Sunday-Monday), starting approximately 4 weeks out, ongoing/permanent, near the Financial District. The agent then said 'let me see if I can get a nightly price for two nights' (5:45) and 'I'll have myself or someone get in touch with you shortly' (6:27). This means the proposal creation is being done FOR Vince by a human, not BY Vince on the platform. Krug's principle of muddling through (Ch.2, Fact of Life #3) predicts that if Vince were asked to create a proposal himself on the platform, he would attempt it without fully understanding the system — selecting dates, pricing, and terms based on vague assumptions rather than clear understanding. The proposal creation interface must be as self-evident as Krug demands: the guest should be able to configure their desired terms without needing to understand the platform's internal model of how proposals work.

user_state.emotional_state: Uncertain but trusting the agent. Vince corrected his own date mistake (6:27-6:43: 'Actually, I'm sorry. I'm thinking about it. I think what I mean is Sunday, Monday'), showing he is thinking carefully but still working out his own needs. He trusts the agent to handle the complexity.
user_state.knowledge_level: Vince knows his desired nights (Sunday-Monday), approximate start date (4 weeks), and duration (ongoing). He does NOT know the nightly rate, the total monthly cost, how proposals work on the platform, what terms are negotiable, or what a ghost roommate match involves.
user_state.commitment_level: Medium. He has invested time in a phone call and shared his preferences. But he is waiting on his employer to confirm his schedule, creating a natural pause point that could become a permanent exit.
user_state.data_available: Desired nights (Sunday-Monday), start date (~4 weeks), duration (ongoing), location preference (near Financial District), amenity requirement (kitchen), flexibility openness (willing to change to 1 night/week if schedule changes).

reasons: Vince's schedule is not yet confirmed — if his employer delays, he may lose momentum

dropout_risk.evidence: Vince at 4:38-4:58: 'What is the rate book like? You know, how much would this cost? So obviously it would depend on how many nights you need. Um, and I'd have to get back to you.' — Vince cannot even see pricing without human mediation. If the platform's proposal creation requires pricing knowledge Vince does not have, the form becomes an impossible task. Krug Ch.2 (p.26-28): 'Faced with any sort of technology, very few people take the time to read instructions. Instead, we forge ahead and muddle through, making up our own vaguely plausible stories about what we're doing and why it works.'

key_quotes.quote: Actually, I'm sorry. I'm thinking about it. Uh, I think what I mean is Sunday, Monday, I'm supposed to be in the office Monday, Tuesday. So I think the nights I want to stay might be something like that.
key_quotes.relevance: Vince struggles to translate his work schedule (Monday-Tuesday office days) into the nights he needs to book (Sunday-Monday nights). This is exactly the kind of mental translation Krug warns against. The proposal interface must help guests convert 'days I work in the office' to 'nights I need to book' without requiring them to do the math themselves.

key_quotes.quote: Is there a times when I could just do one night a week, like if after six months or two months by schedule changes from just going in once a week... is that too little on your end?
key_quotes.relevance: Vince is already thinking about future flexibility before he has even created a proposal. The proposal creation interface must visibly communicate that terms can change, or the fear of being locked in will prevent commitment.

key_quotes.quote: The most important thing you can do is to just understand the basic principle of eliminating question marks.
key_quotes.relevance: The proposal form must eliminate every question mark: what nights am I selecting? What will this cost per month? Can I change later? What happens next? Each unanswered question is a potential dropout point.

negotiation.what_this_lens_reveals: The call does not reach formal negotiation, but it contains a critical proto-negotiation moment. Vince asks about flexibility (5:06-5:25: 'Is there a times when I could just do one night a week?') and the agent responds with two mechanisms: ghost roommate schedule compatibility and the in-app date trading feature (5:25-5:39: 'through our app, once you're in a rental agreement, you can actually change your dates on the flat using the app. So if your roommate wanted to buy a night from you...'). Vince responds 'Right, right. Okay.' — but the question is whether he actually understood this. Krug's muddling-through principle suggests he processed enough to feel reassured but did not fully comprehend the mechanism. During actual negotiation — when a host counters a proposal or terms need adjustment — the interface must make the changes self-evident. Krug's convention principle demands that counter-offers, term changes, and price adjustments follow patterns Vince has seen before (e-commerce checkout modifications, travel booking changes), not novel interaction patterns unique to this platform.

user_state.emotional_state: Reassured but not deeply comprehending. The agent's explanation of flexibility satisfied Vince's anxiety, but his brief 'Right, right. Okay' suggests surface-level processing, not deep understanding.
user_state.knowledge_level: Vince has heard that dates can be changed via an app and that nights can be traded with a ghost roommate. He does NOT understand the mechanics: who initiates, what the cost implications are, whether there are limits, or what the UI looks like.
user_state.commitment_level: Medium. The flexibility reassurance moved him forward, but he is still waiting on external factors (employer schedule confirmation).
user_state.data_available: Vince's flexibility concern (might drop to 1 night/week), openness to schedule changes, awareness that date trading exists.

reasons: If a host counters Vince's proposal with different terms, Vince must understand what changed and why — if this is not self-evident, he will abandon rather than puzzle through it

Vince's schedule uncertainty means negotiation may involve multiple rounds of date adjustments, each of which must be frictionless
dropout_risk.evidence: Vince at 5:25-5:39 hears about the date change feature and says 'Right, right. Okay.' — This is classic satisficing: he accepted the first reassuring answer without verifying his understanding. Krug Ch.2 (p.26): 'We don't figure out how things work. We muddle through.' If negotiation requires Vince to use the date change tool before he has ever seen it, he will muddle through — or give up.

key_quotes.quote: Through our, the company is called Splitly it's and through our app, once you're in a rental agreement, you can actually change your dates on the flat using the app. So if your roommate wanted to buy a night from you or you wanted to buy a night from them, that's entirely doable as well.
key_quotes.relevance: The date-trading concept is introduced verbally but never demonstrated. When Vince encounters it on the platform, it must be self-evident — not require him to recall a verbal explanation from weeks earlier.

key_quotes.quote: Conventions are your friends... Web conventions only become conventions if they work. Well-applied conventions make it easier for users to go from site to site without expending a lot of effort figuring out how things work.
key_quotes.relevance: Negotiation and counter-offer flows must follow conventions Vince already knows from e-commerce (cart modification, booking changes). Novel negotiation mechanics unique to this platform will force him to think.

acceptance.what_this_lens_reveals: Acceptance is not reached in this call. The call ends with the agent promising to follow up with pricing and availability. But the call reveals what acceptance must feel like for Vince: confirmation that his specific terms are met (Sunday-Monday nights, kitchen, near Financial District, ongoing, ~4 weeks start), clarity on what he will pay per month, and reassurance that he can change terms later. Krug's 'don't make me think' principle applies directly: the acceptance confirmation must be a single, scannable summary of exactly what Vince agreed to, not a legal document or multi-page contract. Krug's visual hierarchy principle demands that the most important information (dates, location, monthly cost) be the most prominent, with lease details and terms available on demand but not competing for attention.

user_state.emotional_state: Not yet at acceptance. Projected state based on call evidence: Vince will feel cautious optimism tempered by residual uncertainty about his schedule. He will want clear, simple confirmation that matches what was discussed on the phone.
user_state.knowledge_level: At acceptance, Vince will need to know: exact monthly cost, exact nights, exact location, what happens if his schedule changes, what the lease terms are. Currently he knows none of these with certainty.
user_state.commitment_level: Will be high IF the acceptance experience is frictionless. Vince has invested time in a call, shared his preferences, and expressed genuine interest. But the gap between 'interested' and 'committed' is bridged by the acceptance UX.
user_state.data_available: All proposal terms (dates, location, price, duration), lease documents, ghost roommate match details.

reasons: If the acceptance flow presents too much legal text or unfamiliar terminology, Vince will hesitate

An acceptance flow that requires careful reading of long documents will feel like an obstacle, not a milestone. key_quotes.quote: And just ongoing, or did you have a certain end date in mind? Um, no. It's permanent job. Um, so it's, yeah, it's current situation or the ongoing.
key_quotes.relevance: Vince's commitment is ongoing, not time-boxed. The acceptance confirmation must reflect this: 'ongoing arrangement starting [date], renewable' — not a fixed-term lease that creates anxiety about what happens at the end.

key_quotes.quote: Omit needless words. The art of not writing for the Web.
key_quotes.relevance: The acceptance/confirmation page must follow Krug's principle of radical brevity. Every word on the acceptance page that is not essential to Vince's decision is noise that delays commitment.

move_in.what_this_lens_reveals: The call does not address move-in logistics directly, but Vince's questions reveal what will matter to him at move-in. He asked about storing personal items (prompted by the agent's mention at 2:10-2:20: 'you're able to store your stuff in between stays, like toiletries and monitors and whatever you need there'), and this storage detail was important enough that the agent proactively raised it. Vince's move-in experience will be defined by whether reality matches the mental model built during the call: a space that is '100 percent yours' when he is there, where his stuff is waiting, with a kitchen he can use. Krug's principle that 'making pages self-evident is like having good lighting in a store: it just makes everything seem better' (Ch.1, p.19) applies directly to the House Manual and check-in instructions. First-time move-in is the moment when the listing's promises become physical reality. If the House Manual requires thinking — finding the key, understanding cleaning protocols, locating stored items — Vince's initial experience will be negative, regardless of how good the space is.

user_state.emotional_state: Projected: anxious excitement. First time in a shared-living arrangement, first time at this specific space. Vince will be comparing reality to the mental image built from the listing and the phone call.
user_state.knowledge_level: Vince will know the address, his scheduled nights, and the basic concept. He will NOT know: key handoff procedure, cleaning expectations, storage locations, house rules, what to do if something goes wrong, or how to contact the host.
user_state.commitment_level: Fully committed (has signed lease), but psychologically still evaluating. The first stay is a confirmation or rejection of the decision to sign.
user_state.data_available: Full lease terms, House Manual, check-in instructions, host contact, cleaning protocols, emergency procedures.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: The call reveals that Vince's active lease will be defined by schedule flexibility. He explicitly asks about reducing to one night per week (5:06-5:25) and the agent introduces the date-change tool (5:25-5:39). Vince's ongoing needs are: tracking his scheduled nights, changing dates when his work schedule shifts, understanding what he owes each month, and communicating with his ghost roommate (or avoiding the need to). Krug's conventions principle demands that the Leases page, Date Change Tool, and payment tracking follow patterns Vince already knows. If the Date Change Tool requires learning a new interaction pattern, Vince will default to texting the agent or ghost roommate instead — bypassing the platform entirely. Krug's visual hierarchy principle means the Leases page must prioritize: (1) upcoming stays with dates and location, (2) total monthly cost, (3) tools to change dates. Everything else is secondary.

user_state.emotional_state: Settled but watchful. Vince will be in an ongoing arrangement and his emotional state will fluctuate based on whether the experience matches the 'feel like home' promise. Schedule changes from his employer will create periodic anxiety about whether his arrangement can adapt.
user_state.knowledge_level: By the active lease phase, Vince should understand the basics. But based on his 'Right, right. Okay' response to the date-change explanation, he may not fully understand the date-trading mechanism until he needs to use it.
user_state.commitment_level: High (signed lease, ongoing arrangement). But commitment can erode if the platform creates friction in routine tasks (date changes, payment tracking) or fails to adapt to his schedule changes.
user_state.data_available: Full lease history, payment records, stay history, date change history, ghost roommate schedule, cleaning photos, host contact.

The platform fails this test at every phase where a novel concept is introduced.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Satisficing governs all guest decisions — Vince takes the first reasonable option and does not optimize
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Vince found one listing in Nolita and reached out (1:02). When asked about alternatives, he immediately agreed (3:52-4:02: 'Yeah'). When told dates can be traded, he said 'Right, right. Okay' (5:39) without asking how. Krug Ch.2 (p.24): 'Most of the time we don't choose the best option — we choose the first reasonable option.' The platform must optimize for delivering the first reasonable match quickly, not for displaying maximum options.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Schedule-to-nights translation is a persistent cognitive burden that spans the entire journey
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Vince himself made a translation error during the call, initially saying 'Monday, Tuesday' (3:20) before correcting to 'Sunday, Monday' (6:34-6:43: 'Actually, I'm sorry. I'm thinking about it. I think what I mean is Sunday, Monday, I'm supposed to be in the office Monday, Tuesday. So I think the nights I want to stay might be something like that'). The agent acknowledged this is common: 'thinking of the days you need with the backing up to the nights, that isn't completely understandable' (6:43-6:56). This mental translation (office days to booking nights) will recur every time Vince changes dates, reviews his schedule, or evaluates a proposal. The platform must perform this translation automatically. Krug Ch.1 (p.15): 'every question mark adds to our cognitive workload.'

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Flexibility anxiety is the dominant emotional thread — Vince needs visible escape hatches at every phase
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Vince's schedule is uncertain from the start (0:39: 'I'm still waiting on them to make things official'). He asks about reducing nights (5:06-5:25). He learns about date trading (5:25-5:39). He corrects his own date selection (6:34-6:43). Every interaction is colored by the question: 'What if things change?' The platform must answer this question visibly at every phase — not buried in FAQ or terms, but as a prominent, reassuring element. Krug's visual hierarchy principle demands that flexibility messaging be high in the hierarchy, not hidden.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Human-to-digital handoff creates a trust and comprehension gap that the platform does not bridge
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: The agent mentions handing Vince to a colleague (6:03-6:11: 'I might have my colleague reach out to you cause he's better with like the calendar'). Vince will go from one human to another human to eventually a digital platform. Each handoff loses context and trust. Krug Ch.1 (p.15): 'the fact that the people who built the site didn't care enough to make things obvious — and easy — can erode our confidence in the site and its publishers.' The platform must feel like a continuation of the human conversation, not a separate system. Existing library element works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming) addresses this for hosts; the same principle applies to guests.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Scanning behavior means only the most visually prominent information will be processed — everything else is invisible
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Vince scanned the listing and extracted: location and kitchen. He missed: service concept, pricing model, roommate mechanics, flexibility options, storage. Krug Ch.2 (p.21): 'What they actually do most of the time is glance at each new page, scan some of the text, and click on the first link that catches their interest.' At every phase, only information at the top of the visual hierarchy will be seen. The platform must ruthlessly prioritize what occupies that top position: at discovery it is the service concept, at listing evaluation it is the ghost roommate model, at proposal creation it is monthly cost, at active lease it is upcoming stays and date-change access.
